intro: Spachea ossana, commonly known as the ghost orchid, is a rare and enigmatic flowering plant native to the wetlands of Florida and Cuba. It is a member of the orchid family and is characterized by its delicate, white, spider-like flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant is epiphytic, meaning it grows on the surface of trees without deriving nutrients from them, relying instead on air and rain for sustenance. Spachea ossana has a unique root system that allows it to absorb moisture and nutrients from the surrounding environment. Due to its habitat specificity and sensitivity to environmental changes, it is considered a vulnerable species.
